Description: The Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs entered into an agreement with federal contractor Hillshire Brands Co., formerly Sara Lee Food & Beverage, to resolve claims of systemic hiring discrimination. The settlement followed an investigation by OFCCP that determined Hillshire violated Executive Order 11246 by discriminating against 2,474 men who applied for semiskilled machine operator jobs at the company's sandwich production plant in Florence.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/opa/media/press/ofccp/OFCCP20141669.htm

Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2001/October/531enrd.htm

Description: The U.S. Department of Justice and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced a Clean Air Act (CAA) settlement with Tyson Foods Inc. and several of its affiliate corporations to address threats of accidental chemical releases after anhydrous ammonia was released during incidents at facilities in Kansas, Missouri, Iowa and Nebraska, resulting in multiple injuries, property damage and one fatality. Under the consent decree, Tyson will pay a $3.95 million penalty. Tyson has also agreed to implement a supplemental environmental project to purchase $300,000 worth of emergency response equipment for first responders in communities with significant environmental justice concerns in which Tyson operates facilities
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/settlement-tyson-foods-address-multiple-releases-anhydrous-ammonia

Description: Tyson Foods Inc. pleaded guilty to 20 felony violations of the federal Clean Water Act at its Sedalia, Missouri poultry plant and agreed to pay a $5.5 million penalty to the federal government.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2003/June/03_enrd_383.htm
https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2011/2011-42.htm

Description: Tyson Foods Inc. agreed to pay a $4 million criminal penalty to resolve Foreign Corrupt Practices Act charges relating to improper payments by company representatives to government-employed inspection veterinarians in Mexico.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/tyson-foods-inc-agrees-pay-4-million-criminal-penalty-resolve-foreign-bribery-allegations

Description: The U.S. Department of Labor's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs announced  that Tyson Foods Inc. entered into six consent decrees to settle findings of hiring discrimination by giving more than 2500 women and minorities a total of $1.5 million in back pay.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20170608130519/https://www.dol.gov/opa/media/press/esa/archive/ESA20061658.htm

Description: gender
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/ofccp/foia/files/TysonCA_Redacted.pdf

Description: Tyson Foods, Inc. agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle allegations that in proxy statements filed with the SEC from 1997 to 2003 it made misleading disclosures of perquisites and personal benefits provided to its former chairman both prior to and after his retirement.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2005-68.htm

Description: While not admitting liability for hiring discrimination allegations, Tyson Foods, Inc. agreed to pay $1.6 million in back wages, interest and benefits to 5,716 applicants rejected for laborer jobs from 2007 to 2010 at its facilities in Amarillo, Houston and Sherman, Texas; Rogers and Russellville, Arkansas; and Santa Theresa, New Mexico. The company has also agreed to extend job offers to 474 of the affected workers as positions become available, and to revise its hiring and training practices.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/ofccp/ofccp20161004-0

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: The Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs announced that Tyson Fresh Meats Inc. entered into two consent decrees to settle allegations of sex discrimination. The company agreed to pay a total of $2.25 million in back wages, interest and benefits to more than 1,650 qualified female job applicants who were rejected for employment at facilities in Joslin, Ill.; West Point, Neb.; and Waterloo and Denison, Iowa.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/opa/media/press/ofccp/OFCCP20110799.htm

Description: Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc. agreed to pay a $2,026,500 civil penalty to settle allegations that it violated terms of a 2002 consent decree and a federally-issued pollution discharge permit at its meat processing facility in Dakota City, Nebraska.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/tyson-fresh-meats-inc-pay-more-2-million-discharges-nebraska-plant
https://www.gipsa.usda.gov/Newrelease/2011NR.pdf

Description: The Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs announced that Tyson Refrigerated Processed Meats Inc.  agreed to settle findings of hiring discrimination against 157 African-American and 375 Caucasian applicants for laborer positions at the company's bacon processing plant in Vernon., Texas.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/opa/media/press/ofccp/ofccp20101461.htm

Description: Racial discrimination. This case, which began as a lawsuit over the failure to promote any of a group of African-American supervisors when filling an opening for plant manager, ended up as a controversy over the use of ther term "boy" when referring to one of the supervisors. After numerous proceedings at the appellate level, that supervisor was allowed to keep a $364,049 verdict and his lawyers ultimately were awarded $551,716 in fees and costs.
Private Litigation Case Title: Ash, et al v. Tyson Foods, Inc, et al
Info Source: http://abelllaw.typepad.com/kentucky_employment_law/2012/01/5th-time-the-charm-the-eleventh-circuit-reverses-itself-and-allows-to-stand-partially-a-2d-jurys-ver.html

Company: The Hillshire Brands Company (Sara Lee Food)
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/ofccp/foia/files/20180928Hillshire-CA-R00182521-SW-Redacted.pdf

Description: Meatpacker IBP agreed to pay $1.85 million to Nebraska to resolve allegations relating to wastewater violations at its plant in Dakota City. This was part of a larger $14.1 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/ne-ibp-inc
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2001/October/531enrd.htm

Description: Tyson Foods agreed to pay at least $539,898 in settlement of allegations its facility at Monett discharged wastewater containing highly acidic animal feed supplement, causing the city's water treatment system to fail and allowing ammonia-contaminated water into Clear Creek, killing at least 100,000 fish.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20161230061423/http://ago.mo.gov/home/news-archives/2015-news-archives/ag-koster-announces-settlement-with-tyson-foods-for-may-2014-clear-creek-fish-kill

Description: Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc. agreed to pay a $30,000 civil penalty, $100,000 to Rock Island County for environmental projects, $50,000 to the City of Rock Island for a children's garden, $45,000 to the City of Moline for environmental cleanup, $600,000 for reducing emissions from Tyson delivery trucks, and $750,000 for installing additional air pollution control equipment, in settlement of allegations of air pollution and permit violations.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20071020181553/http://www.illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2007_01/20070110b.html

Description: Six poultry companies agreed to pay a total of $7.5 million to the City of Tulsa to resolve a lawsuit concerning water pollution. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Info Source: Arkansas poultry firms, Tulsa settle lawsuit over water, Associated Press, July 16, 2003 (via Nexis).

Description: Six poultry companies agreed to pay a total of $7.5 million to the City of Tulsa to resolve a lawsuit concerning water pollution. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among them.
Info Source: Arkansas poultry firms, Tulsa settle lawsuit over water, Associated Press, July 16, 2003 (via Nexis).

NAICS Translation: 112320: Broilers and Other Meat Type Chicken Production

Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Tyson Farms agreed to pay a total of $3 million in civil penalties, restitution and donations to environmental trusts in settlement of allegations it discharged partially treated wastewater into state waters in 2019.
Info Source: https://www.alabamaag.gov/newsviewer/3c9d8f4f-4d5e-4862-a1e5-40282d598b4e

Description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission settled charges against Tyson Foods, Inc. for exceeding the CFTC's position limits for soybean meal futures contracts traded on the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) and for failing to comply with reporting and recordkeeping obligations regarding its cash positions in grains. The order required Tyson to pay a $1.5 million civil monetary penalty and to cease and desist from violating the Commodity Exchange Act and CFTC regulations as charged.
Info Source: https://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/8413-21
https://enfo.gaepd.org/Details/72898
